variant.question: A pilot departs an aerodrome on the West coast of Spain at dawn for a flight to New York. Half an hour after departure, the VHF station for communication can no longer be received. What are two of the main reasons that VHF radio range is limited to line of sight?

options.text: No reflection by the ionosphere, and no surface wave.
Absorption by the ionosphere, and no direct waves.
Inversion of polarisation by the ionosphere, and attenuation.
Fading by reflected signals, and limited transmission power.

variant.question: Which one of the following has a limited range?

options.text: TVOR
CVOR
DVOR
VOT

variant.question: Which one of the following has a limited range?

options.text: TVOR
CVOR
VOT
DVOR

variant.question: Which of the following is an advantage of Ground/DF (VDF) let-down?

options.text: It only requires a VHF radio to be fitted to the aircraft
It is pilot interpreted and does not require the assistance of ATC
It does not require any special equipment, apart from a VHF radio, to be installed in the aircraft or on the ground
It does not require any special equipment to be fitted to the aircraft

variant.question: Which of the following is an advantage of Ground/DF (VDF) let-down?

options.text: It only requires a VHF radio to be fitted to the aircraft.
It does not require any special equipment, apart from a VHF radio, to be installed in the aircraft or on the ground.
It is pilot interpreted and does not require the assistance of ATC.
It does not require any special equipment to be fitted to the aircraft.

variant.question: Which of the following statements about the range of VHF waves is correct?

options.text: The range depends on the elevation of the antenna located on the ground and on the altitude of the aircraft.
Mountains or other obstacles located between transmitter and aircraft do not affect the range.
The range is independent of the aircraft altitude. It depends on transmitter power only.
The range is independent of the elevation of the transmitter antenna.
